subject: Japanese Economy Minister Motegi to meet with US Trade Representative Lighthizer om April 25th
Australian Ministry of Finance says Q1 underlying cash balance was a deficit of AUD 8.1bln

PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Crude prices rose to around 6-month highs on US ending Iranian sanction waivers, Samsung Electronics delays Galaxy Fold launch and Asiana Airlines creditors plan KRW 1.6tln capital injection
content:
AUSTRALIA

ASX (ASX AT) - Co.’s efforts to attract fast-growing global tech players is gathering steam with at least eight companies valued more USD 500mln plan to list on the ASX this year. (AFR)

BHP (BHP AT) - Co. CEO affirmed that they have no plan to exit thermal coal operations. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Co named Caltex Executive McMenamin as news CEO of its fuel business. (Newswires)

Energy - Brent crude gained over 3% and WTI was higher by 2.7% with both at their highest levels in around 6 months following the US decision to end Iranian sanctions waivers. (Newswires)

Financials - Hails storms in Sydney and Townsville flooding is reportedly to cost insurers AUD 2.4bln. (AFR)

Other News - Australian government is to pledge AUD 1bln fund to support the creation and growth of 250k new small businesses over the next half-decade. (AFR)

 

JAPAN

Advantest (6857 JT) - Reports notes analyst speculation the Co. could be added to the MSCI index replacing DeNA. (Newswires)

Itochu Corp (8001 JT) - Co. is expected to report FY19 net exceeded guidance of JPY 500bln. (Newswires)

Kyushu Electric Power (9508 JT) - Co. plans to allocate JPY 100bln in preferred shares to Development Bank of Japan, Mizuho Financial Group (8411 JT) Mizuho Bank and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (8306 JT). (Newswires)

Nidec (6594 JT) - Co. is to sell its compressor business to ESSVP IV. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Renault (RNO FP) is said to have made new attempt to integrate with the Japanese automaker, although Nissan is expected to reject the offer and push for a more equal capital relationship. (Newswires)

Toyota (7203 JT) - Co. partners with BAIC (1958 HK) to provide fuel cell equipment and hydrogen tanks to BAIC unit Beiqi Foton Motor. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS) - Co. creditors are planning a KRW 1.6tln capital injection. (Yonhap)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. is to delay the April 26th debut of its Galaxy Fold amid reports of damage to the main display and flickering screens after a couple of days use. (Nikkei)

Samsung Heavy Industries (010140 KS) - Co. receives contract valued at KRW 1.1tln. (Newswires)

subject: China approves launch of 7 funds to invest in the tech board
US President Trump will conduct a state visit to the UK in June and will visit Buckingham Palace
Tesla (TSLA) plans to launch self-driving taxis in some US cities next year
China should fine-tune its monetary policy on economic growth and price changes, according to Xinhua citing a top-level meeting chaired by President Xi
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include New Zealand Card Spending, Japanese BoJ Core CPI and 2yr JGB Auction
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Australian government is to pledge a AUD1bln fund to support the creation and growth of 250k new small business over the next half-decade. (AFR)

UK/EU

UK Conservative Party activists to hold emergency summit for vote of no-confidence in UK PM May after over 70 heads of local Conservative associations signed a petition calling for an extraordinary general meeting with PM May's position at the top of the agenda. Furthermore, reports added that the vote would be non-binding but could pressure the 1922 Committee to take action to oust PM May. (Newswires/FT)

A member of the 1922 committee stated that their leader Brady is set to meet the PM May this week to set a date for her departure with May 22nd or June 30th suggested, according to ITV's Brand. (Twitter) 

COMMODITIES

US decided not to renew any Iranian oil import waivers in May according to a White House Statement with the decision intended to bring Iran exports to zero, while the US, Saudi Arabia and UAE agreed to take action to ensure global demand is met and Iraq also commented that it is ready to increase their oil exports by 250k BPD based on needs of the market. (Newswires)

US administration official said between 700-800k BPD of oil is affected by ending Iranian waivers and sees no need to consider tapping SPR in the aftermath of ending waivers. The US is also to look for ways to prevent Iranian attempts to bypass sanctions and stated that a retaliatory move by Iran to close the Strait of Hormuz would be unacceptable, while a State Department Official said the Iranian waiver wind-down period will be one-year. (Newswires)

Iran stated that Tehran is in touch with partners regarding the end of US waivers and that the expiry of US waivers have no value, while it was also reported that Iran is to close the Strait of Hormuz if prevented from using it. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the Kingdom would like to reiterate its longstanding policy of working towards oil market stability and will cooperate with other oil suppliers to ensure adequate supply. Furthermore, he added that they will consult with other oil producers over the next few weeks, that oil supplies will be available to consumers and the oil market will not go out of balance. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said Herman Cain has requested not to be nominated to the board of the Federal Reserve and that he will respect Cain's wishes. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Energy names, including ExxonMobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), were buoyed as oil prices rose on the news that the US would not renew Iranian oil import exemptions for eight countries in May; worth noting Halliburton (HAL) also caught a tail wind after a strong earnings report. US homebuilders including Lennar (LEN) and DR Horton (DHI) opened lower as the yield curve bear steepened and continued to fall after existing home sales missed expectations, before paring slightly. Boeing (BA) traded lower after the NYT reported that workers were under pressure to not report safety violations in the production of its 787 Dreamliner. Netflix (NFLX) benefitted from a positive note at Morgan Stanley, whose streaming video survey sees the streaming co. extending its leadership in terms of both usage and original content. Tesla (TSLA) shares fell after reports circulated that one of its cars exploded in China, four of its board members announced that they would not stand for re-election and CEO Musk criticised its lithium battery supplier Panasonic. The electric automobile maker also announced that Samsung (028260 KS) would make its chips. Samsung also announced a delay to the rollout of their new foldable phone. Under Armour (UAA) fell after Piper Jaffray negative note, with Nike (NKE) also moving lower in sympathy. Pfizer (PFE) and Eli Lily (LLY) opened lower after their co-developed pain killer failed in an advanced stage of the study. Merck (MRK) shares were initially buoyed after the pharma co.’s Kidney cancer drug Keytruda won FDA approval.  Kimberly-Clark (KMB) shares rose after the personal care co. reported increased profits and sales that fell less than expected. W. W. Grainger Inc (GWW) fell after the industrial supply company reported mixed Q1 earnings and management pointed to a weaker demand environment. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) plummeted after the medical robotics firm missed bottom line expectations in its Q1 earnings report. Kraft Heinz (KHC) was initially lifted after the company announced it was bringing in Anheuser-Busch InBev CEO Miguel Patricio, before paring gains to finish flat. Constellations Brands (STZ) shares moved higher after the firm benefitted from an upgrade at Jeffries. Blackstone (BX) moved higher after the private equity firm agreed to acquire a majority stake in Indian packaging supplier Essel Propack. SPX +0.10% at 2908, NDX +0.3% at 7713, DJI -0.2% at 26513.

Action was thin, as players were away for the long-weekend. But the bias was towards bear-steepening, with shorter yields up around 1bps, while the long-end of the curve was up around 3bps by settlement. Reports suggested specs, day traders and dealers were sellers from the 10-year through the 30-year space, with HFs selling across the curve. Some had also suggested that the sharp rise in oil prices was applying upwards pressure on yields. US T-note futures (M9) settled 6+ ticks lower at 122-30.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
US MARKET WRAP 22 April 2019: Crude at YTD highs as US to end Iran waivers
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities flat/higher, dollar down, Treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Iran waivers to end; US existing home sales misses; Cain withdraws Fed nomination; Thin holiday trade

* AHEAD: US New Home Sales; EZ Consumer Confidence (Flash); US & EuroUS 2-year Action;

* TOMORROW’S EARNINGS: United Technologies, Coca-Cola, Verizon, P&G, Sherwin Williams, eBay, State Street, Twitter, Lockheed Martin, Nextera, Northern Trust, Edwards Lifesciences, FirstEnergy, Texas Instruments, TD Ameritrade Holding, Stryker.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 1.70 HIGHER AT USD 65.70/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD 2.07 HIGHER AT USD 74.04/BBL. Crude traded at fresh YTD highs as the US will not renew waivers that allowed eight countries (China, Greece, India, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Turkey) to continue buying Iranian crude without incurring sanctions, with the intention to squeeze Iranian exports to zero (the nation's exports are running at a pace of 0.8mln BPD in April, according to Eikon data). The waivers are set to formally expire on 2 May, though a State Department Official said the waiver-wind down period would be one year. US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US will end Iranian oil waivers for eight countries in May, Iran import will go to zero, adding that Saudi Arabia and UAE, as well as the US, has committed to ensure appropriate oil supply, and suppliers were working with Iranian customers to help the switch. This was followed-up by US President Trump, who said that the Saudis (who have recently been cutting supply by more than was required for the OPEC+ output cut agreement) would make up for the absence of Iranian crude on the international market (a Saudi source previously said the nation will first assess the impact on the oil market before raising output, but the nation was willing to compensate for any loss of supply). China, the largest international buyer of Iranian crude, again said it opposes unilateral US sanctions on Iran. A few questions remained unanswered: what is the pace of the wind down to be? One Indian source stating that from the beginning, there was talk of a gradual reduction and not going to zero in one swipe (India is the second largest buyer of Iranian crude). Some desks have also noted that the news comes as crude participants are awaiting developments on OPEC+ production policy, after recent questions whether Russia is fully committed to extending the supply cut agreement with OPEC partners, as it faces a dilemma between losing market share to the US, or competing for market share at lower oil price. Elsewhere, Eastern Libyan National Army stepped up its assault on Tripoli with airs strikes and heavy clashes reported over the weekend, although reports suggested that the Zawiya port and El Sharara oilfield are both still open.

* US EXISTING HOME SALES: March existing home sales fell to 5.21mln from 5.48mln in February, a larger fall than the expected 5.3mln. “February’s leap in sales never looked sustainable so a hefty correction was inevitable,” analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics note. They go on to highlight that the fall was less than what the market had feared may have been the case due to the slump in the pending home sales index. Rates have come back down significantly from their peak at the end of last year, and there have been SALT changes, both working as a tail wind for this year’s mortgage applications. “The rising trend in mortgage applications points clearly to rising existing home sales over the next few months, so inventory should fall, and prices should firm somewhat. The trend rate of increase for single-family home prices is now just under 4%, having slowed from almost 7% in the spring of 2017, but we don’t expect a further significant downshift,” the consultancy concludes.

* SPX +0.10% at 2908, NDX +0.3% at 7713, DJI -0.2% at 26513. SECTORS: Communications +0.0%, Cons Discretionary -0.2%, Cons Staples -0.0%, Energy +2.1%, Financials -0.3%, Healthcare +0.1%, Industrials -0.3%, Materials -0.7%, Tech +0.2%, Telecoms +0.7%, Utilities -0.1%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Energy names, including ExxonMobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), were buoyed as oil prices rose on the news that the US would not renew Iranian oil import exemptions for eight countries in May; worth noting Halliburton (HAL) also caught a tail wind after a strong earnings report. US homebuilders including Lennar (LEN) and DR Horton (DHI) opened lower as the yield curve bear steepened and continued to fall after existing home sales missed expectations, before paring slightly. Boeing (BA) traded lower after the NYT reported that workers were under pressure to not report safety violations in the production of its 787 Dreamliner. Netflix (NFLX) benefitted from a positive note at Morgan Stanley, whose streaming video survey sees the streaming co. extending its leadership in terms of both usage and original content. Tesla (TSLA) shares fell after reports circulated that one of its cars exploded in China, four of its board members announced that they would not stand for re-election and CEO Musk criticised its lithium battery supplier Panasonic. The electric automobile maker also announced that Samsung (028260 KS) would make its chips. Samsung also announced a delay to the rollout of their new foldable phone. Under Armour (UAA) fell after Piper Jaffray negative note, with Nike (NKE) also moving lower in sympathy. Pfizer (PFE) and Eli Lily (LLY) opened lower after their co-developed pain killer failed in an advanced stage of the study. Merck (MRK) shares were initially buoyed after the pharma co.’s Kidney cancer drug Keytruda won FDA approval.  Kimberly-Clark (KMB) shares rose after the personal care co. reported increased profits and sales that fell less than expected. W. W. Grainger Inc (GWW) fell after the industrial supply company reported mixed Q1 earnings and management pointed to a weaker demand environment. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) plummeted after the medical robotics firm missed bottom line expectations in its Q1 earnings report. Kraft Heinz (KHC) was initially lifted after the company announced it was bringing in Anheuser-Busch InBev CEO Miguel Patricio, before paring gains to finish flat. Constellations Brands (STZ) shares moved higher after the firm benefitted from an upgrade at Jeffries. Blackstone (BX) moved higher after the private equity firm agreed to acquire a majority stake in Indian packaging supplier Essel Propack. 

* FED: The WSJ on the weekend reported that Fed officials are to begin discussing conditions under which they would cut interest rates, including a scenario where inflation drifts lower even if the economic growth doesn't falter. Such a scenario isn't seen as particularly likely, the newspaper said, and a rate cut is not imminent or under consideration for their meeting 30/April to 1/May. US President Trump announced that Herman Cain had requested not to be nominated to board of the Federal Reserve, following the recent resistance from both the Republican and Democratic sides to his nomination. 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 6+ TICKS LOWER AT 122-30. Action was thin, as players were away for the long-weekend. But the bias was towards bear-steepening, with shorter yields up around 1bps, while the long-end of the curve was up around 3bps by settlement. Reports suggested specs, day traders and dealers were sellers from the 10-year through the 30-year space, with HFs selling across the curve. Some had also suggested that the sharp rise in oil prices was applying upwards pressure on yields.

* 2-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 133bln in 2-year (USD 40bln, Tuesday), 5-year (USD 41bln, Wednesday), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thursday), as well as a 2yr FRN (USD 20bln, Wednesday); with USD 107.2bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 25.8bln in new cash. The Fed will allow USD 29.8bln to run off its balance sheet at month-end,and will add on a modest USD 0.6bln to 2s and 5s, USD 0.5bln to 7s, and USD 0.3bln to the FRNs. Recent auctions have been decent, with investors starved for returns, TD Securities said. "While the market has trimmed their pricing for Fed rate cuts to 12bp from 33bp in 2019, investors continue to expect cuts this year and in 2020," the bank says, "we believe that despite solid underlying fundamentals, expectations of a dovish Fed stance will help keep 10y rates pinned in the 2.40-2.60% range," and adds "we similarly expect the Treasury to trim 2-3y auction sizes, aiding demand at the front-end." Recent averages a stop on the screws with a 63% buyside takedown, the bank predicts. It also notes that the sector has cheapened on the curve, which might be supportive.

* PETRO-CURRENCIES: The currencies of oil exporters were up and importers down after crude reached new YTD highs. This follows the US announcing an end to Iranian oil import waivers from May. RUB, CAD and NOK were trading higher against the dollar by between 0.2-0.4% and TRY, INR, KRW were down between 0.3-0.4%.

* JPY: Has done very little, and trades around neutral heading into APAC, largely ignoring PM Abe's ruling block suffered two rare by-election losses on the weekend in Osaka and Okinawa, in an apparent warning from voters not to get complacent ahead of a national election for parliament’s upper house later this year, Reuters reported. Friday's news that the BOJ had cut the size of its long-end Rinban operations saw the Japanese curve bear-steepen; to recap, 10-25yr purchases were cut to JPY 160bln (from JPY 180bln) and 25y+ cur to JPY 40bln (from JPY 50bln). Additionally, UBS notes that for operations of 10yr+, dealers can now sell 100% of the Rinban amounts vs a prior limit of 50%. "This isn't a green light for dealers to offload inventory at every long end operation, rather the sizes have now become much smaller such that it would allow for a more efficient functioning of the market." The BOJ's policy meeting this week will also feature an outlook report, and some desks suggest that the BOJ could announce a new policy, with speculation underpinned by the recent dovish pivot at the Fed and ECB, which might see the BOJ follow suit.

* GBP: The Telegraph reports that MPC members are on course for a split decision on rates at its 2 May meeting, with at least one member to make the case for a rate rise, the newspaper said, citing a source. Elsewhere, Brexit could begin returning to news feeds this weeks, as policymakers return from recess on Tuesday; UK PM May will this week be told that she must step down before the end of June, or Tory lawmakers might change leadership rules to force her out, the Times reported, amid suggestions that 70% of Conservative MPs want her resignation for botching Brexit talks and seeing a collapse in Tory support.

* AUD, NZD: The AUD failed to capitalise on the commodity upside, trading down around 0.3% heading into APAC trade whilst the Kiwi fell 0.2%. The Aussie slipped beneath its 200dma, while the NZD saw a bearish outside week, technicians note. Some desks remind us there is no Tier one data out of China this week, which might support the Antipodes, while the market looks to Aussie CPI on Wednesday, with Citi's analysts expecting the AUD to react more to downside than upside given that the RBA is laying the ground for potential dovish policy. However, with the labour market in strong shape, it will likely require a turning of the labour market to the downside to catalyse an imminent cut from the RBA, rather than spot inflation, Citi said.

* BRL: The Brazilian Pension Secretary said the government will announce changes in the Pension Bill later on Monday and on Tuesday morning. The House’s Constitution and Justice Commission will then vote on the constitutionality of the proposed changes on Tuesday. Rabobank’s baseline scenario remains that effective pension reform will go ahead, reducing pension spending by 30% over 10 years, supporting their BRL projection of 3.70 against the dollar for the end of the year. However, the bank suggests that “slow-moving negotiation is poised to keep feeding higher perceptions of execution risks.”

subject: SPX MOC 35mln to sell (unchanged vs 1544 EDT)
US T-Note (M9) futures settle up 6+ ticks at 122-30
analysis_details:

subject: Phillips 66 (PSX) says Carson (refinery capacity 160k BPD) crude unit has restarted operations following a fire
WTI futures (K9, expires) settle USD 1.70 higher at USD 65.70; Brent Futures settle USD 2.07 higher at USD 74.04

subject: Dow Inc (DOW) to lock workers out of Houston-area chemical plant later today, follows USW union rejecting latest contract proposal
Brazil Pension Secretary to announce changes in the pension bill later on Monday, and on Tuesday morning
UK Conservative Party activists to hold emergency summit for vote of no-confidence in UK PM May, according to the FT
content: Via FT

subject: Monster (MNST) sees downside on reports that CEO and CFO compensation in 2018, which was up YY from 2017
US Envoy to Iran Hook says waivers were granted in November because conditions in the oil market did not permit zero exports and the picture is now very different
US Administration Official says between 700-800k BPD of oil affected by ending Iranian waivers
CNBC's Najarain notes unusual option activity in Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) and Box Inc (BOX) shares
US President Trump says Herman Cain has requested not to be nominated to the board of the Federal Reserve, says he will respect his wishes
US Administration Official says any retaliatory move by Iran to close the Strait of Hormuz would be unacceptable, says sees no need to consider tapping SPR in the aftermath of ending waivers
content: • says US will look for ways to prevent Iranian attempts to bypass sanctions

subject: Evercore ISI reportedly cuts Tesla (TSLA) 2019 delivery estimates to 369k units (vs estimate of 402k units previously)
Iraq says it is ready to increase their oil exports by 250k BPD, based on needs of the market
Libya NOC says Zawiya port is open, El Sharara oilfield (300-315k BPD) is working as normal
analysis_details:
• The port is scheduled to load 6 mln barrels in April

Prior to this it was reported that the Eastern Libyan National Army stepped up its assault on Tripoli with air strikes and heavy clashes reported over the weekend.

subject: Russia has raised its gold holding by 19.4 tonnes to 2,148.37 tonnes in March 2019
Turkey has criticised US' decision to end Iranian oil waivers, adding that it will not help with regional peace and stability
Daily FX Wrap: Commodity FX steals limelight during holiday thinned trade
content:
CAD – The stand-out G10 outperformer, more-so on the rise of oil prices after the US refused to grant extensions to Iranian oil waivers. USD/CAD resides just above the 1.3350 level having fluctuated in a 1.3355-94 intraday range ahead of the BoC rate decision this week.

AUD, NZD – The Aussie meanders around its 100 DMA at 0.7136 (having fallen below its 200 DMA last week), potentially on the back of subdued base metal prices with copper briefly losing the 2.90/lb handle in intraday trade. Meanwhile, NZD moves lower in sympathy with its Antipodean counterpart. Some desks remind us there is no Tier one data out of China this week which might support the Antipodes, while the market looks to Aussie CPI on Wednesday, with Citi's analysts expecting the AUD to react more to downside than upside given that the RBA is laying the ground for potential dovish policy. However, with the labour market in strong shape, it will likely require a turning of the labour market to the downside to catalyse an imminent cut from the RBA, rather than spot inflation.

EUR, GBP – The single currently largely mirrored USD moves amid a catalyst-deprived environment. EUR/USD resides around the 1.1250 level ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.1292. Elsewhere, Sterling is marginally softer against its G10 counterparts with Brexit risk seemingly crawling back into focus as the UK parliamentary recess ends tomorrow. Weakness in the Pound ahead of the US open coincided with a tweet by ITV’s Paul Brand, noting that 1922 Committee Chair Brady seeks top inform PM May of her departure date, which could either be May 22nd (EU elections) or June 30th (her requested Brexit extension date). Cable currently trades little changed just under 1.3000 ahead of its 200 DMA (1.2967) and 100 DMA (1.2955) 

JPY – The Japanese currency largely ignored PM Abe's ruling block suffered two rare by-election losses on the weekend in Osaka and Okinawa, in an apparent warning from voters not to get complacent ahead of a national election for parliament’s upper house later this year, Reuters reported. Friday's news that the BOJ had cut the size of its long-end Rinban operations saw the Japanese curve bear-steepen at the tail end of last week. As a reminder, Thursday will see the BoJ’s latest rate decision which will include the Inflation Outlook report. The report will also take the first look into FY 2021, with sources stating that the Central Bank are to project FY 21 inflation above 1.5% but short of its 2% target, and FY 19 growth and inflation forecasts are expected to be cut.

EM – Mostly dictated by the energy complex as exporters benefit more-so than the importers as oil prices climb to YTD highs. USD/RUB lost the 64 handle having trading in a 63.75-64.06 range whilst importers such as Turkey, China and South Korea all bear the brunt of the firmer energy prices. USD/TRY advances above 6.7000 (vs. high 6.7190) whilst USD/CNH, USD/INR and USD/KRW all drifted higher as US disallowed a renewal of waivers on Iranian oil.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Commodity FX steals limelight during holiday thinned trade
content:
CAD – The stand-out G10 outperformer, more-so on the rise of oil prices after the US refused to grant extensions to Iranian oil waivers. USD/CAD resides just above the 1.3350 level having fluctuated in a 1.3355-94 intraday range ahead of the BoC rate decision this week.

AUD, NZD – The Aussie meanders around its 100 DMA at 0.7136 (having fallen below its 200 DMA last week), potentially on the back of subdued base metal prices with copper briefly losing the 2.90/lb handle in intraday trade. Meanwhile, NZD moves lower in sympathy with its Antipodean counterpart. Some desks remind us there is no Tier one data out of China this week which might support the Antipodes, while the market looks to Aussie CPI on Wednesday, with Citi's analysts expecting the AUD to react more to downside than upside given that the RBA is laying the ground for potential dovish policy. However, with the labour market in strong shape, it will likely require a turning of the labour market to the downside to catalyse an imminent cut from the RBA, rather than spot inflation.

EUR, GBP – The single currently largely mirrored USD moves amid a catalyst-deprived environment. EUR/USD resides around the 1.1250 level ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.1292. Elsewhere, Sterling is marginally softer against its G10 counterparts with Brexit risk seemingly crawling back into focus as the UK parliamentary recess ends tomorrow. Weakness in the Pound ahead of the US open coincided with a tweet by ITV’s Paul Brand, noting that 1922 Committee Chair Brady seeks top inform PM May of her departure date, which could either be May 22nd (EU elections) or June 30th (her requested Brexit extension date). Cable currently trades little changed just under 1.3000 ahead of its 200 DMA (1.2967) and 100 DMA (1.2955) 

JPY – The Japanese currency largely ignored PM Abe's ruling block suffered two rare by-election losses on the weekend in Osaka and Okinawa, in an apparent warning from voters not to get complacent ahead of a national election for parliament’s upper house later this year, Reuters reported. Friday's news that the BOJ had cut the size of its long-end Rinban operations saw the Japanese curve bear-steepen at the tail end of last week. As a reminder, Thursday will see the BoJ’s latest rate decision which will include the Inflation Outlook report. The report will also take the first look into FY 2021, with sources stating that the Central Bank are to project FY 21 inflation above 1.5% but short of its 2% target, and FY 19 growth and inflation forecasts are expected to be cut.

EM – Mostly dictated by the energy complex as exporters benefit more-so than the importers as oil prices climb to YTD highs. USD/RUB lost the 64 handle having trading in a 63.75-64.06 range whilst importers such as Turkey, China and South Korea all bear the brunt of the firmer energy prices. USD/TRY advances above 6.7000 (vs. high 6.7190) whilst USD/CNH, USD/INR and USD/KRW all drifted higher as US disallowed a renewal of waivers on Iranian oil.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 22nd April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker is facing fresh pressure after a parked Tesla vehicle spontaneously exploded in Shanghai
  • Boeing (BA)  - The NY Times reported that the co.’s production of 787 Dreamliner jets is problematic
  • Halliburton (HAL) Q1 adj. EPS USD 0.23 vs. exp. USD 0.22, revenue USD 5.74bln vs. exp. USD 5.52bln

 

22nd April 2019

EARNINGS

  • Grainger (GWW) Q1 adj. EPS USD 4.51 vs. exp. USD 4.44, revenue USD 2.8bln vs. exp. USD 2.88bln. Affirms FY19 sales growth of 4%-8.5% vs. exp. USD 11.88bln. (Newswires)
  • Halliburton (HAL) Q1 adj. EPS USD 0.23 vs. exp. USD 0.22, revenue USD 5.74bln vs. exp. USD 5.52bln. (Newswires)
  • Kimberly-Clark (KMB) Q1 adj. EPS USD 1.66 vs. exp. USD 1.54, revenue USD 4.6bln vs. exp. USD 4.53bln. Backs FY19 adj. EPS view USD 6.50-6.70 vs. exp. USD 6.60, backs FY19 organic sales growth of 2% vs. exp. USD 18.31bln. (Newswires)
  • Lennox (LII) Q1 adj. EPS USD 1.68 vs. exp. USD 1.40, revenue USD 790mln vs. exp. USD 747.31mln; reaffirms FY19 adj. EPS view in line with expectations. (Newswires)
  • Steel Dynamics (STLD) Q1 EPS USD 0.91 vs. exp. USD 0.98, revenue USD 2.8bln vs. exp. USD 2.83bln. The co. said it expects North American steel demand to grow throughout the year. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Boeing (BA)  - The NY Times reported that the co.’s production of 787 Dreamliner jets is problematic, citing workers at its South Carolina plant complaining that they are under pressure to not report violations, such as defective manufacturing and debris left on planes; Boeing has since responded saying that the story paints a “skewed and inaccurate picture”. (NY Times/Newswires)
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) – The energy major has signed a 20-year LNG agreement with Zhejiang Provincial Energy Group, where Exxon will deliver 1mln metric tons of LNG per annum. (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan Chase (JPM) – The bank is looking to expand its use of blockchain technology in the process of validating payments. (FT)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharma giant’s pinnacle Keytruda therapy, in combination with Inlyta, has been granted FDA approval for the treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma, following the results from the Phase 3 KEYNOTE-426 trial. (Newswires)
  • Pfizer (PFE), Eli Lily (LLY) – A non-opioid painkiller developed by the two pharma companies has failed a late-stage study in patients with osteoarthritis, having been initially touted as a potential hit. (Newswires)
  • Visa (V) – The credit card provider has appointed its CEO, Alfred Kelly, to the position of Chair of the Board, effective April 16th. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Eli Lilly (LLY) – The pharma co.’s anti-rheumatic drug, Taltz, has met its primary and secondary endpoints in the COAST-X Phase 3 trial. (Newswires)
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) – The automaker is recalling 300,000 cars - Dodge Dart compact cars made from 2013 through 2016 - in North America over issues with cabling that may cause the vehicles to roll away unexpectedly. (Newswires)
  • Jacobs Engineering (JEC), KeyW (KEYW) – The construction co. is to acquire competitor KeyW (KEYW) for USD 11.25 per share, for an enterprise value of USD 815mln, which assumes USD 272mln of net debt. (Newswires)
  • Kroger (KR) – WSJ reports that the supermarket chain has been lagging behind competitors such as Walmart (WMT) and Target (TGT) in regard to adopting new technology and shifting to online sales, which the publication states is evident in its slowing top line growth. (WSJ)
  • Newmont Mining (NEM), Barrick Gold (GOLD) – The two goldminers’ JV in Nevada has passed all regulatory hurdles, which is now set to create the world’s largest gold producing site. (Newswires)
  • T-Mobile US (TMUS), Sprint (S) – T-Mobile CEO John Legere attempted to defend the proposed USD 25.6bln acquisition of Sprint to Justice Department officials, where there are concerns that the transaction would negatively affect consumers. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s publication writes that health care stocks UnitedHealth (UNH), Anthem (ANTM), Cigna (CI), Humana (HUM) and CVS (CVS) have appealing valuations after being sold off on fears of a healthcare for all presidential candidate. The publication writes cautiously on Spotify (SPOT), Boston Beer (SAM) and Pinterest (PINS). (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Facebook (FB) – The FTC is mulling whether to hold the social media giant’s CEO Mark Zuckerberg personally accountable for the co.’s mishandling of data, following the commission’s privacy probe. (Washington Post)
  • PayPal (PYPL), Synchrony Financial (SYF) – PayPal’s Venmo unit is looking into a partnership with Synchrony for a Venmo credit card, which could be announced this year. (WSJ)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) – the chipmaker will close a joint venture with China’s Guizhou province at the end of the month, after the two reportedly invested a joint USD 570mln in Huaxintong Semiconductor (HXT) as of August 2018. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker is facing fresh pressure after a parked Tesla vehicle spontaneously exploded in Shanghai. The co. also announced that four of its existing board members (Brad Buss, Antonio Gracias, Stephen Jurvetson, and Linda Johnson) will not stand for re-election at the end of their respective terms. CEO Elon Musk has publicly criticised its lithium-ion battery cells supplier, Panasonic, for hampering Tesla’s production rate, this comes amidst the two companies debate whether to expand their partnership. Elsewhere, WSJ reports that CEO Elon Musk is gathering investors on Monday to unveil the co.’s latest attempt at self-driving technology, two days before its earnings report, which is expected to show a fall in vehicle sales. (Newswires/WSJ)

OTHER NEWS

  • Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) – The household goods co. has announced a board transformation, where nine out of ten directors will be independent, six of which are women. In addition, the board has formed a new Business Transformation and Strategy Committee. (Newswires)
  • Emcor Group (EME) – The construction co. has become a potential takeover target for the French energy co. Engie, for the approximate value of USD 4.5bln. (Newswires)
  • ON Semiconductor (ON) – The chipmaker is to acquire a 300mm fabrication plant for USD 430mln from GLOBALFOUNDRIES in New York, where USD 100mln has been payed up front, and the remainder will be payed at the end of 2022. (Newswires)
  • Rent-A-Center (RCII) – The rented household goods co. has reached a settlement with Vintage Capital and B. Riley Financial in regard to the termination of the Agreement and Plan of Merger from June 2018, Rent-A-Center will receive USD 92.5mln of cash. (Newswires)
  • Taiwan Semiconductors (TSM) – The chipmaker’s CEO, CC Wei, has said that the co.’s 7nm process utilisation rate is expected to rise significantly in H2 2019 as demand for smartphones picks up due to seasonal factors. (DigiTimes)
  • Teva (TEVA) – The pharma co. has received FDA approval to bring its generic nasal spray used for the treatment of opioid overdoses, known as Narcan, to market. (Newswires)
  • Uber (UBER), Lyft (LYFT) – Investors and academics have suggested that following the IPOs of the two ride-hailing apps, fare prices are expected to rise as investors scrutinise their losses more. (WSJ)

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • ACCELERON (XLRN) ASSUMED WITH AN OUTPERFORM FROM PERFORM AT OPPENHEIMER
  • CANOPY GROWTH (CGC) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT GMP SECURITIES
  • COMMSCOPE (COMM) REINSTATED WITH AN OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN
  • LAM RESEARCH (LRCX) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT B. RILEY FBR
  • MANHATTAN ASSOCIATES (MANH) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SUNTRUST
  • NEUROCRINE (NBIX) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN
  • NEWMONT MINING (NEM) UPGRADED TO ACTION LIST BUY AT TD SECURITIES
  • RENT-A-CENTER (RCII) UPGRADED TO STRONG BUY FROM OUTPERFORM AT RAYMOND JAMES :
  • VIAVI (VIAV) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN

 

Downgrades

  • ADIENT (ADNT) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT BUCKINGHAM
  • ANADARKO (APC) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT PIPER JAFFRAY
  • AUTOLIV (ALV) DOWNGRADED TO SECTOR WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT KEYBANC
  • D.R. HORTON (DHI) DOWNGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT KEEFE BRUYETTE
  • DOVER (DOV) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT BAIRD
  • DXC TECHNOLOGY (DXC) DOWNGRADED TO BUY FROM CONVICTION BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS
  • GRAFTECH (EAF) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM BUY AT CITI
  • OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM (OXY) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT MIZUHO
  • ONEOK (OKE) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT SEAPORT GLOBAL
  • SCHLUMBERGER (SLB) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT TUDOR PICKERING
  • TESLA (TSLA) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM IN LINE AT EVERCORE ISI ON DECLINING MODEL S & X DEMAND

 

Initiations

  • AGENUS (AGEN) RATED NEW BUY AT B RILEY FBR, INC.; PT USD 5
  • OUTLOOK THERAPEUTICS INC (OTLK) RATED NEW BUY AT ASCENDIANT; PT USD 4
  • PRECISION BIOSCIENCES (DTIL) RATED NEW BUY AT GOLDMAN; PT USD 24
  • PRECISION BIOSCIENCES (DTIL) RATED NEW BUY AT JEFFERIES; PT USD 25
  • PRECISION BIOSCIENCES (DTIL) RATED NEW OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS; PT USD 24
  • PRECISION BIOSCIENCES (DTIL) RATED NEW OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN; PT USD 23
  • RETROPHIN (RTRX) RATED NEW OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS; PT USD 36
  • SIX FLAGS (SIX) RATED NEW HOLD AT JEFFERIES; PT USD 56

  • WATFORD HOLDINGS (WTRE) RATED NEW EQUAL-WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS; PT USD 29

 

Ex-Dividends

subject: US Secretary of State Pompeo says US will end Iranian oil waivers for 8 countries in May, Iran import will go to zero; says Saudi Arabia, UAE have committed to ensure appropriate oil supply, supplier working with Iranian customers to help switch
content:
• Says how long we aim to hold exports at zero is up to Iran, depends on when Iran addresses issues
  • Says happy to get outcome, of Iranian exports to zero, however we can achieve it
  • Says Iran has diminished power as a result of campaign, sanctions have cost the country USD 10bln
  • Says those who don’t abide by US wishes will face sanctions and US intends to enforce sanctions
  • Says US President Trump has spoken to Saudi and UAE to ensure adequate supply in the market
  • Says there are no waivers to extend beyond 2 May

subject: Russian President Putin and North Korean Leader Kim are set to meet at the end of April, according to sources citing Kremlim
US Open Briefing 22nd April
content:
EQUITIES: On the tail-end of a long-weekend for Europeans and US players, interest in Asia equities was light. In stock specific news, Huawei unveiled its first ever quarterly results, where Q1 revenue was up 39% to USD 27bln, and its net profit margin was around 8% in the quarter (slightly higher than the same period last year, though it did not specify a figure). Elsewhere in tech, Samsung has postponed media events for its Galaxy Fold planned for this week days after reports of defects in models sent to reviewers. China equities were lower after the Politburo saw downward economic pressure as structural in nature, adding that external economic environment was 'tightening' and it would step up proactive fiscal policy; the Central Financial Committee reiterated plan to increase financial support for real economy, and will fine tune monetary policy on growth and prices. 

 * ENERGY: Crude traded at fresh YTD highs on multiple reports that the US will not renew waivers that allowed eight countries (China, Greece, India, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Turkey) to continue buying Iranian crude without incurring US sanctions. The waivers are set to formally expire on 2 May, and US Secretary of State Pompeo is reportedly to announce the decision on Monday. Sources said that the US will offset the loss of Iranian crude by announcing commitments from Saudi Arabia and UAE - a Saudi source said the nation will first assess the impact on the oil market before raising output, but the nation was willing to compensate for any loss of supply; an Iraq oil ministry spokesperson, however, said any decision to adjust output but be collectively taken by OPEC. China, the largest international buyer of Iranian crude, again said it opposes unilateral US sanctions on Iran. The move would represent a victory for foreign policy hawk John Bolton, who have argued that the US take a firm approach to push Iranian crude exports to zero (the nation's exports are running at a pace of 0.8mln BPD in April, according to Eikon data), after the Trump Administration pulled out from the 2015 Nuclear Accord with Iran in May last year. However, hope remains that the US might allow some crude from Iran, with one Indian source stating that from the beginning, there was talk of a gradual reduction and not going to zero in one swipe (India is the second largest buyer of Iranian crude). Some desks have also noted that the news comes as crude participants are awaiting developments on OPEC+ production policy, after recent questions whether Russia is fully committed to extending the supply cut agreement with OPEC partners, as it faces a dilemma between losing market share to the US, or competing for market share at lower oil price. In recent news flow, as a sign of escalating tensions reports indicate that Iran are to close the strait of Hormuz if they are prevented from using it. Elsewhere, Eastern Libyan National Army stepped up its assault on Tripoli with air strikes and heavy clashes reported over the weekend.  

* TREASURIES: Overnight, 10yr JGBs were flat amid the indecisive risk tone, and with prices nursing the weakness after last Friday’s BoJ Rinban reduction. The US Treasury will auction USD 133bln in 2s/5s/7s as well as a 2yr FRN; with USD 107.2bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 25.8bln in new cash. The Fed will allow USD 29.8bln to run off its balance sheet at month-end, and will add on a modest USD 0.6bln to 2s and 5s, USD 0.5bln to 7s, and USD 0.3bln to the FRNs. The WSJ on the weekend reported that Fed officials are to begin discussing conditions under which they would cut interest rates, including a scenario where inflation drifts lower even if the economic growth doesn't falter. Such a scenario isn't seen as particularly likely, the newspaper said, and a rate cut is not imminent or under consideration for their meeting 30/April to 1/May. 

 * USD: The USD seems more bid against EMs rather than G10 FX, after news that waivers allowing some nations to purchase Iranian crude could end or be tapered on 2 May, and traders take a cautious stance in thin trade, where European players are away for the long Easter weekend. Currencies of crude importers are facing pressure (INR, KRW both down around 0.3% vs the USD), but crude exporters fared better (CAD, RUB up around 0.2% and 0.3% vs the USD respectively).  

* GBP: The Telegraph reports that MPC members are on course for a split decision on rates at its 2 May meeting, with at least one member to make the case for a rate rise, the newspaper said, citing course. Elsewhere, Brexit could begin returning to news feeds this weeks, as policymakers return from recess on Tuesday; UK PM May will this week be told that she must step down before the end of June, or Tory lawmakers might change leadership rules to force her out, the Times reported, amid suggestions that 70% of Conservative MPs want her resignation for botching Brexit talks and seeing a collapse in Tory support.  

* JPY has largely ignored PM Abe's ruling block suffered two rare by-election losses on the weekend in Osaka and Okinawa, in an apparent warning from voters not to get complacent ahead of a national election for parliament’s upper house later this year, Reuters reported. Friday's news that the BOJ had cut the size of it's long-end Rinban operations saw the Japanese curve bear-steepen at the tail end of last week. To recap, 10-25yr purchases were cut to JPY 160bln (from JPY 180bln) and 25y+ cur to JPY 40bln (from JPY 50bln). Additionally, UBS notes that for operations of 10yr+, dealers can now sell 100% of the Rinban amounts vs a prior limit of 50%. "This isn't a green light for dealers to offload inventory at every long end operation, rather the sizes have now become much smaller such that it would allow for a more efficient functioning of the market." The BOJ's policy meeting this week will also feature an outlook report, and some desks suggest that the BOJ could announce a new policy, with speculation underpinned by the recent dovish pivot at the Fed and ECB, which might see the BOJ follow suit.  

* AUD, NZD: The Aussie slipped beneath its 200dma, while the NZD saw a bearish outside week, technicians note. Some desks remind us there is no Tier one data out of China this week which might support the Antipodes, while the market looks to Aussie CPI on Wednesday, with Citi's analysts expecting the AUD to react more to downside than upside given that the RBA is laying the ground for potential dovish policy. However, with the labor market in strong shape, it will likely require a turning of the labor market to the downside to catalyse an imminent cut from the RBA, rather than spot inflation, Citi said.   

* SPAIN ELECTION: Spain's Socialists extended their lead in an ABC poll ahead of elections on Sunday, though at 31.5% still lack a majority.

subject: IRANIAN OIL SANCTION WAIVERS: ANALYSIS
content:
* SUMMARY: Overnight, multiple reports suggested that the US will cease Iranian oil purchasing waivers. US Secretary of State Pompeo is said to announce this in early US hours on Monday [at 8:45 ET], according to sources. Alongside the announcement, sources added that Pompeo will also unveil commitments from other suppliers (such as Saudi and UAE) to offset the loss from the waiver expiries. Oil prices spike to YTD highs on the news, with Brent crude jumping as much as 3%, to levels last seen in November; the WTI/Brent Arb widened to over -8.30/bbl vs. USD -8/bbl on Thursday (and around USD -7/bbl last Monday).

* BACKGROUND: Last year, after the US pulled out of the 2015 between Iran and six other countries, it placed sanctions on Iran’s financial system before introducing a second set of sanctions on oil supply in November. To avoid a spike higher in oil prices, the US granted eight countries temporary waivers to import Iranian oil, set to expire on May 2nd, 2019, in return, the US asked for countries to reduce Iranian oil imports to zero.

* CURRENT WAIVERS:

  • CHINA – Allowed to import as much as 360k BPD of Iranian oil
  • SOUTH KOREA – 200k BPD of ultra-light oil, i.e. condensate
  • INDIA – Permitted to import as much as 300k BPD of crude oil
  • JAPAN – Tanker tracker data showed March loadings of just over 100k BPD
  • TURKEY – Permitted to purchase around 60k BPD
  • TAIWAN - Reduced Iranian oil imports to zero
  • ITALY - Reduced Iranian oil imports to zero
  • GREECE - Reduced Iranian oil imports to zero

* RHETORIC: Some desks have also noted that the news comes as crude participants are awaiting developments on OPEC+ production policy, after recent questions whether Russia is fully committed to extending the supply cut agreement with OPEC partners, as it faces a dilemma between losing market share to the US, or competing for market share at lower oil price.

* SAUDI – The Kingdom may reportedly be willing to increase output to offset the losses resulting from the waiver expiries, according to a Saudi source. It is however unclear how this will clash with the OPEC output reduction pact.

* CHINA – China Foreign Minister spokesmen, when asked about the reports on waivers, noted that China has consistently opposed US’ implementation of unilateral sanctions.

* INDIA – India is said to be hoping that US will provide some sort of flexibility regarding Iranian oil sanction waivers, according to sources familiar with US-India talks.

* IRAN – Oil Ministry source stated that the US will fail at cutting Iranian oil exports to zero. Energy Journalist Reza Zandi noted that potential reactions from Iran may include: 1) Oil supply may be disturbed, 2) US is harming oil market stability via the sanctions and 3) Concerns on the security of global energy supply. There has been a suggestion that Iran might close the Straits of Hormuz if prevented from using it, it was reported on Monday, in a sign of increasing geopolitical tensions.

* US – Iranian Special Representative Hook previously cautioned that the sudden removal of Iranian crude from the market (around 1mln BPD) could cause a spike in prices, he recently highlighted that the US was “on the fast track to zeroing out all purchases of Iranian crude”.

subject: Iran to close the straight of Hormuz if prevented from using it, according to FARS
content: • Via Twitter

subject: Northern Trust Corp (NTRS) Q1 EPS USD 1.48 vs. exp. USD 1.47

THE SERVICE IS NOW CLOSED DUE TO EUROPEAN-WIDE CLOSURES AND WILL RESUME AGAIN AT 1300BST FOR THE US SESSION
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded indecisive amid Easter holiday closures, crude soared on reports US is to end Iran sanctions waivers
content:
Asia equity markets were mixed as the region lacked conviction amid holiday-thinned conditions with Australia, New Zealand and Hong Kong all closed for holidays. Nikkei 225 (Unch.) traded indecisive with the index dampened by recent currency moves and after last week’s cut in the BoJ’s Rinban operation which some analysts suggested was a form of tapering. KOSPI (-0.2%) was stable above the 2200 level and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) underperformed amid the absence of Hong Kong participants, while the PBoC also refrained from liquidity operations and there were additional views regarding unlikelihood of near-term action from China’s central bank in which OCBC suggested a recent statement by the Politburo suggested limited room for additional policy easing. Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat amid the indecisive risk tone and with prices nursing the weakness after last Friday’s BoJ Rinban reduction.

In FX markets, price action was mostly uneventful with the DXY marginally softer after a slight pullback from last week’s data-driven gains but remained above the 97.00 level amid a subdued tone in most its major counterparts. EUR/USD and GBP/USD were lacklustre amid European-wide market closures including the UK for Easter Monday with the latter also having recently given up the 1.3000 handle, although the quiet tone could be short-lived with Parliament set to return from the Easter recess on Tuesday and with PM May facing increased pressure from within the Tory party ranks to stepdown or face being ousted. Elsewhere, continued strength in crude prices has benefitted the CAD, while antipodeans were less emphatic amid weakness in China and with AUD/USD also dampened by cross-related flows in which AUD/NZD and AUD/JPY gave up the 1.0700 and 80.00 handles respectively.

Oil stole the limelight overnight in which Brent crude futures briefly broke above USD 74.00/bbl with gains of as much as 3.2%, while WTI crude closely followed and broke firmly above the USD 65.00/bbl level on several bullish supply-side factors including reports that the US is to announce the end of Iran oil sanction waivers and an increased offensive by Khalifa Hafter forces on Libya’s capital over the weekend. In addition, the latest Baker Hughes rig count also showed a decline in active rigs, while some also noted the recent win by United Conservative Party’s Kenney in Alberta, Canada was another tailwind for the energy complex as he had previously threatened legislation to ‘turn off the taps’ that would allow Alberta to restrict the amount of energy leaving the province. Elsewhere, gold prices were marginally higher amid mild softness in the greenback overnight and copper was subdued amid the indecisive risk appetite in the region but with downside stemmed amid strength in Chinese commodity prices in which Dalian iron ore and Shanghai Rebar gained around 3% at the open.

content:
HDFC Bank (HDFCB IS) - Co. March quarter net rose 22.6% Y/Y to INR 58.9bln. (ET)

Jet Airways (JETIN IS) - Tata Group is considering making an offer to acquire the troubled airline. (Newswires)

RBI Minutes - RBI Minutes stated that they are to watch for evolving growth as well as inflation data and act accordingly, while Governor Das stated that with inflation outlook benign and inflation below target, challenges to growth must then be addressed, while he added they need to consider rate adjustments and not in the conventional way of 25bps or multiples thereof. (Newswires)

Financials - RBI said it has not issued any direction in regards to imposing a 5-day working week for commercial banks. (Moneycontrol)

Other News - Congress Party leader Gandhi says PM Modi will definitely lose the elections and Bahujan Samaj Party’s Mayawati also suggested PM Modi is losing, while PM Modi stated that the country has decided to elect his BJP party again. (Newswires)

subject: China's market regulator plans to hold a meeting with some cement producers on Wednesday regarding competition
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed amid Easter holiday closures, crude surges with US to end Iran sanctions waivers
content:
Asia equity markets are mixed as the region lacks conviction amid holiday-thinned conditions with Australia, New Zealand and Hong Kong all closed for holidays. Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) is indecisive with the index dampened by recent currency moves and after last week’s cut in the BoJ’s Rinban operation which some analysts suggested was a form of tapering. Elsewhere, the KOSPI (Unch.) is stable above the 2200 level and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) is lacklustre amid the absence of Hong Kong participants, while the PBoC also refrained on liquidity operations and there were additional views regarding unlikelihood of near-term action from China’s central bank in which OCBC suggested a recent statement by the Politburo suggested limited room for additional policy easing.

In FX markets, price action is mostly uneventful with the DXY marginally softer after a slight pullback from last week’s data-driven gains but remains above the 97.00 level amid a subdued tone in most its major counterparts. EUR/USD and GBP/USD are lacklustre amid European-wide market closures including the UK for Easter Monday with the latter also having recently given up the 1.3000 handle, although the quiet tone could be short-lived with Parliament set to return from the Easter recess on Tuesday and with PM May facing increased pressure from within the Tory party ranks to stepdown or face being ousted. Elsewhere, continued strength in crude prices has benefitted the CAD, while antipodeans were less emphatic amid weakness in China and with AUD/USD also dampened by cross-related flows in which AUD/NZD and AUD/JPY gave up the 1.0700 and 80.00 handles respectively.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat amid the indecisive risk tone and with prices nursing the weakness after last Friday’s BoJ Rinban reduction, while the biggest mover overnight were oil futures with Brent up over 3% and WTI following closely behind on supply concerns with the US set to end Iran sanctions waiver and amid increased fighting in Libya over the weekend.
